speaker: James
text: [dry] Angela Merkel's 'Wir schaffen das' was presented as a moral imperative. Historically? It was an aberration.

speaker: Elena
text: An 'aberration'? Or simply a modern state responding with compassion to a humanitarian crisis? We're not in the 3rd century BC.

speaker: James
text: For five millennia, every successful civilisation controlled its borders. Tightly. The idea of large-scale, culturally distinct immigration as a principle is barely 60 years old in the West.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a rather sweeping generalisation, isn't it? The Romans absorbed many peoples. The Ottomans were a mosaic.

speaker: James
text: [clipped] The Romans granted citizenship with exquisite care. Until they didn't. The Ottomans managed groups, they didn't make them interchangeable. Big difference.

speaker: Elena
text: But you're ignoring the context. The post-war West needed labour. We built these economies on it.

speaker: James
text: Gastarbeiter were explicitly temporary. They didn't go home, did they? That's the crucial point.

speaker: Elena
text: Well, cultures change, people settle. Is that so bad? Diversity is strength.

speaker: James
text: [sardonic] 'Diversity is strength.' A lovely slogan. The Sumerians had specific laws barring non-citizens from owning land. Athenians restricted citizenship to those born of two Athenian parents. Aristotle couldn't vote.

speaker: Elena
text: That's ancient history! We've evolved beyond that narrow view of belonging. Surely?

speaker: James
text: The Chinese built a wall. The Japanese closed their country for 200 years and produced one of the most culturally cohesive societies on Earth. They understood the principle.

speaker: Elena
text: A wall? Sakoku? Those are extreme examples, not models for a modern, globalised West.

speaker: James
text: They were effective. The Ming rebuilt the Wall after expelling the Mongols. Not against a specific threat, but against the *principle* of uncontrolled entry.

speaker: Elena
text: No, that's completely wrong. You're presenting a selective history. You're ignoring the economic benefits, the cultural enrichmentâ€”

speaker: James
text: Are we? The data doesn't quite back that up. Look at the fiscal impact studies.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait, what fiscal impact?

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] Danish Ministry of Finance, 2018. Non-Western immigrants, a net fiscal cost of 33 billion DKK per year. Dutch Central Planning Bureau: average non-Western immigrant, a net lifetime fiscal cost of EUR 43,000.

speaker: Elena
text: That's... selective, isn't it? What about the EEA migrants the UK MAC found were net contributors?

speaker: James
text: Precisely my point. Culturally and economically similar, net positive. Dissimilar, net negative. It's an accounting fact, not a moral judgement.

speaker: Elena
text: But you're reducing people to numbers. What about the human element? The refugees?

speaker: James
text: The article isn't moralising. It's presenting the historical pattern and the economic data. It's a question of sustainability.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, fine. I'll give you the fiscal data looks... challenging for certain groups. But integration is key, right? We just need to do better at it.

speaker: James
text: But the data on integration, Elena? Third-generation North Africans in France, unemployment rates double the national average. Swedes, Somali, Afghan, Iraqi immigrants below 40% employment after ten years. These are not isolated incidents.

speaker: Elena
text: Well... okay, that's harder to argue with than I expected. But it doesn't mean it's impossible. We just need to invest more.

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] And then there's Putnam's work on social trust. Ethnic diversity reducing trust, not just between groups, but within them. That's a profound cost.

speaker: Elena
text: I remember that. He was a liberal, trying to disprove his own findings. And he couldn't.

speaker: James
text: Exactly. It's been replicated globally. Rapid, large-scale demographic change has real costs for social cohesion. Costs our policymakers consistently ignore.

speaker: Elena
text: So, what's the alternative then? Shut the gates entirely? Go full Japan?

speaker: James
text: The article suggests three scenarios: the Roman path, the Japanese correction, or the Singapore model. Remember our 'Decline of the West' piece? That's the Roman path.

speaker: Elena
text: The Roman path... where citizenship became meaningless, and the army was filled with foederati. That's a grim parallel.

speaker: James
text: Indeed. The distinction between Roman and barbarian blurred. Odoacer, a Roman general, deposed the last Western emperor. Not a conquest, but a change of management.

speaker: Elena
text: But the Singapore model... strict economic contribution, no family reunification, easy to lose residency. That feels... cold.

speaker: James
text: It's pragmatic. And historically, it's what every successful civilisation did before 1965. Including, for most of its history, the United States.

speaker: Elena
text: The 'nation of immigrants' was actually quite restrictive. Hart-Celler really changed everything.

speaker: James
text: Senator Ted Kennedy promised it wouldn't change the ethnic mix. He was profoundly wrong. Foreign-born share went from 4.7% to 14%.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, okay. I get it. The historical evidence is... quite compelling that the West is on an unprecedented experiment.

speaker: James
text: And public opinion has consistently rejected it for fifty years. The Brexit vote, the rise of the AfD. The gap never closes.

speaker: Elena
text: So, we're either heading for a Roman-style fragmentation, or we need a dramatic correction. But what about the moral argument? Isn't there still a duty of care?

speaker: James
text: A duty of care to whom? Our own citizens? Future generations? History suggests that ignoring these structural forces leads to collapse, not moral triumph. The gates are still in our hands, as the article puts it. The question is, do we have the will to use them?
